description:
What is not to love about this place! 
Grew up eating roasted duck from here since the age of 7 
My dad loves this place. That says it all
author: Fiona B.

description:
Solid 4.5 on the food.

I got the soy sauce chicken over rice for $7.00
Great quality and great portions.

First time I saw this place there was a line out the door. They frequently sell out around dinner time.
author: Justin F.

description:
As a non-chinese person, I've gotta say, I really enjoyed the soy sauce chicken even though I have nothing to compare it to. Ask for sliced ginger on the side and eat along with rice for a great flavor combination.

First off, they always have a line, but patience is a virtue and the price is right, so wait your ass off.

The few times I have ordered here, their roast duck is always sold out which is unfortunate. 

I have a few questions: What's the difference between yellow soy sauce chicken and soy sauce chicken? Is there even a difference? Do they serve actual pigeons?

Will I come back? Of course! I only paid $20 for two half orders of soy sauce chicken, with 2 ginger sides, 2 cups of rice, and a lemon tea which fed my boyfriend and I for two separate meals.

Drawback: the language barrier :-(!!!!! At least food is a universal language.
author: Rebecca B.

description:
$15 min for credit card

Was recommended this spot by a coworker for Chinese bbq and it's pretty legit.

I came to grab some duck and chasiu (or bbq pork) for takeout on a Saturday, a little after noon, and there was a short line out the door. I probably waited for 15 minutes before it was my turn to order.

There are some tables if you want to eat there as well, but I was there strictly for takeout. My coworker really likes the chasiu (barbecue pork) and the soy sauce chicken here, so even though I'm not big on chasiu I decided to try it out. 

The barbecue pork is $8/lb, and the roast duck is $10 for half or $19.50 for a whole duck. I bought two pieces of the pork and a whole duck and walked out with my wallet $32 lighter. Not too bad, but somehow still more than I was expecting to spend.

The chasiu was definitely one of the best ones I've had, in my limited experience. It's well flavored and not dry at all. However, it does run on the sweet side, so I ended up cooking it at home with some low sodium soy sauce to try and get it to be a little bit more savory. The duck was pretty standard and I enjoyed every bite of it.

This place isn't too far from me, so I definitely see myself coming back whenever I get a craving for Chinese bbq!
author: Dianna H.

description: Food was great! It was hard to park though. I had chicken takeaway and the taste was really good and authentic as you can get from a Hong Kong local cafe.
author: Christy Z.

description:
So my family took me here saying that their duck was oh so good.

Not understanding how this could be the best Chinese BBQ ever considering I felt that the duck

1) didn't have enough spices compared with say Cheung Hing
2) was cold given the line out the door one would think it would b fresher
3) didn't have that crispy delicious skin that great duck has

Given the price and the hard to find parking I wouldn't go out of my way to come here.

If you're in the area then by all means come here, but don't go out of your way to search for and go to this place, because it's just average.
author: Jack R.

description:
Delicious, affordable and great value. I thought the rice plates were plentiful and well balanced.  We had the duck, soy sauce chicken, and cha siu. All were tender juicy and well seasoned. The ginger scallion sauce was very tasty. I would recommend this place if you want a quick meal or for catering of bbq meats and rice.   

They have a server who will take your order at the table, but if you want takeout you wait in the deli line. Our server was a woman with glasses and short bob haircut. She was very sweet helpful and courteous. Our daughter spilled her glass of water and the woman came over with a towel to wipe it up, brought a new cup of water and a stack of napkins. Unfortunately most places like this have rude servers, so I took notice today of the great service. Will be back soon!

$15 min for credit card purchases.
author: Jamie W.

description:
My favorite chicken place . I grew up eating the half and whole chicken (Soy Sauce Chicken and  from this beloved establishment. 

Cantonese staff.
author: Fanny T.

description: Worst service. It was our first time as it was recommended by a friend.  The chicken wasn't even that good and the staff was very rude because we didn't speak Chinese. They were out of a lot of the menu items as well. Will never come back.
author: Allen W.

description: Princess chicken was tasty but the chickens and ducks are getting smaller and smaller every time we go back.  Time to plan ahead and just poach my own bird and save $$$
author: D R.

description:
Ordered whole soy sauce chicken for about $17 at 4:30pm Sunday with a few people sitting and about 3 people in front for to go then 5 mins later about 8 people behind our to go libe lol. This place doesnt seem busy at first with 3 chickens hanging and a few pIeces of BBQ pork and nothing on the steam table but dont be fooled on a weekend. 

The chicken was not warm since there are no heat lamps and we came in just before they start to get busy. But this small-medium sized chicken seem to LOW AMOUNT OF FAT and that is better than some places.
author: Organic T.

description:
This place is so popular! Long line on a gloomy Sunday afternoon, but it goes fast. The Chinese BBQ rice box runs around 9ish-10$. A lot of rice, but my box was kind of skim on the meat. Not going to complain. Love the ginger sauce that accompanies the rice box. Supposedly one of the best in the city and I definitely see why. 

I think their popular items are: princess chicken and the BBQ pork neck. Can take to go or dine in.
author: Tina S.

description:
I agreed with the reviewer. They really do give less meat.   BBQ pork and roast duck over rice for $9.75.  Only 5 slice of BBQ porks and 4 pieces duck,not worth to come here again.  They still use plastic container for to go food.   I suggest you should go the place across from McDonald. 

9/18/2018I went there and brought roast duck and bbq pork.  You guys have to watch how they cut the meat.  They are very SNEAKY they will took some pieces away and save it to sell individual rice dish.  If you buy whole chicken or Duck, they took the chicken head ,neck and duck head away without ask the customers.  Their roast duck and bbq pork taste bland.  Roast Duck mostly Fat.  Their prices are MORE EXPENSIVE and watch out they are SNEAKY/ greedy.
author: Jade L.

description:
I'm sad that I lived next to Ming Kee for so many years, without knowing it existed. Ming Kee is a super legit Chinese deli on Ocean Avenue, and there's a reason you often see a line out the door.

I would advise ordering their soy sauce chicken, roast duck, or char siu to go. Also, be sure to get extra containers of their ginger scallion oil (not free, but very delicious). We picked up a few white take-out boxes of meat for a delicious, keto-friendly picnic in Golden Gate Park - yum!

Cash only.
author: Claire S.

description: Our family loves their soy sauce chicken here! One of the best in SF, compared to other places they cut their pieces smaller and sized correctly. Their roast duck and princess chicken is also great as well. Parking is hard to find sometimes so make sure you call in beforehand to see if they have what you want before coming in to order.
author: Leanne W.

description: Best place in SF for classic Cantonese roast items. I moved over here from NYC and it's so hard to find a place like this. All the roast items are delicious and the rice plates that they offer are at a great price too. I especially love their soy sauce chicken and the roast duck. You can get all these items or a great price. But be warned they run out of things fast so don't come here too late or else you won't get what you want!
author: Rachel M.

description:
Best. Chinese. Barbecue. Ever.  

My personal favorites:
Chicken flavorful and fresh.
Cha Shu - tender, juicy, and just the right size.  
Duck - Nice fat to meat ratio! 

They also serve food inside.  Simple rice plates.  Amazing!
author: Debbie C.

description:
This place is primarily a to-go order kind of place and the line is usually several deep during rush hour. They used to be known as 'Happy Bakery' until a fire messed up the part of the building and everyone took a forced holiday for about a year.

This is one of the best authentic Chinese BBQs in SF. Definitely my top 3 for authentic comfort food.
author: andrew v.

description: Don't expect any service here, but they have the Best soy sauce chicken in Bay Area, seriously! I tried many places, sunset, southbay, both Chinatowns & east bay. No one can beat them. Beside the taste, the price is good too! Their price is cheaper than most of the Chinese BBQ place! Also, their chicken & ducks are very clean too (some Chinese place always sell hairy chicken). But, make sure you don't go after 5pm, because they almost sold out everything at that time.
author: MJ C.

description: Superb!  Love the food here.  My second time eating here, just as good as the first.  After I stopped in here the first time, a little intimidated by the whole ordering practice, and the lack of English speakers at the time I went.  But the food is what brought me back.  I started dreaming about the taste and texture of the soy sauce chicken I had, the duck was incredible.  Food reasonably priced, service was quick, but place sometimes is crowded with locals.  Will be back!
author: George S.

description:
The best place to get roast duck in the entire city!  They're constantly cooking up new batches, so everything that you get is guaranteed fresh.  They also never keep anything overnight.  Their soy sauce chicken is also on point as well!  If you get a chance, definitely get some of their roast pork neck (pork jowl).  It's prepared the same way as traditional roast pork, but the extra fat from the pork jowl gives it so much more flavor.  

Do not leave this place without getting a bunch of their ginger scallion oil.  They are $0.50/ea., but it so worth it!  I never leave the restaurant with less than four of them, and I have been called out by the lady at the cash register because she knows how much I love it!  Goes great with any of their meats and rice.  Speaking of which, if you just want a quick meal to go you can always order any of their meats (or a combination of them) over white rice.    

Also, some of the reviews are a bit outdated.  They are no longer cash only and will take Visa/Mastercard for purchases over $15.
author: William L.

description:
Sweet little gem for some to-go food!

Call first to make sure they have what you want and you can get your order faster! Especially if you go later in the day. I've been wanting to try this place for awhile now but every time I tried to make a to-go order through the phone they always had no more rice left =( (Yes having a rice cooker would help but mine is currently broken and I'm too lazy to get it fixed/get a new one). 

This place gets pretty busy with a line out of the door so I suggest you call in to order. Apparently they are known for their BBQ pork (Cha Sew) and I agree with anyone who says their cha sew is the best. It's perfectly cooked, tender, and flavorful.

We got the BBQ pork over rice as well has a BBQ pork and steamed chicken combo over rice. Both includes a TON of rice to last you probably 2 or even 3 meals, some veggies and a generous amount of meat. The chicken was really tasty too. It's moist and not too dry and super delicious with the ginger they give you. 

I really want to try to soy sauce chicken or the roasted duck next time.
author: Sherry L.

description: This place has been my favorite for years but my how things have changed over the years. The chicken and ducks are great here but the service has gotten horrible. Waited in line behind about 10 people, which is fine, but that is not the bad part. When it was my turn, I had to wait because the people in line that are behind me knew the employees that worked there so they get to be served first even when they are at the end of the line. I pointed to the fact that there is a line but the employee explained the rules. According to the employee, the policy is friends get first dibs and other customers have to wait regardless of being in line first. Good food, horrible service so be prepared to wait if there is a line and you do not know any of the workers.
author: Mike G.

description:
Used to eat here once or twice a week and get the to go all the times.
I'm trying to stay away from this place, haven't been back here for more than a month now. They make their rice plates look like a lot. Mainly the no good pieces, not eatables are always hidden under the nice looking pieces. And they slice them so thinly that make it look like a lot of pieces.  I ordered a few times and have to pay extra for the drum stick part soy sauce chicken. It never comes with the whole drum stick, always bad skin part or other white meat part hidden under. I finally got fed up and showed the waitress in two separate occasions and she did not charge me extra. The last occasion the grumpy elderly boss took a look and said "at least there is some part of the drum stick". Yelled, "it's considered a drum stick". She went ahead and charged me extra.
Lots of times the duck rice plate is fat and burned hidden as well.
The latest, I ordered halve soy sauce chicken, halve duck and a bit of the pork cheek to go. The chicken was OK, the duck was hella fat and burned. Almost halve of it was not eatable. The last few times I noticed their foods didn't taste as good as before. And now they are charging an arm and a leg to their customers. I've  been going else where to get my chickens and ducks now. Soon, the rest of her customers are going to do the same and she'll left with no more costumers. Grumpy old greedy lady
author: Judy T.

description: Soy sauce chicken is a must try. They cook it the old fashioned way and it really makes the chicken and the juices tender and delicious. I've had their soy sauce chicken for some time now and I'd have to say that it's the best I've ever had in decades. Trust me, you won't regret it. I'm definitely coming back. Will be back.
author: Anthony T.

description: Go-to spot for HK style BBQ, always top notch! Been coming here for over 10 years, never been disappointed
author: Jennifer S.

description: The pork was really fatty and tasty (I'm a huge fan of oily stuff). I ordered half a pound of that and enjoyed every bite with their spicy sauce. I immediately went back and devoured half a portion of their soy sauce chicken. I feel a bit bloated from consuming so many calories in one sitting but would probably do it again:P
author: Risako O.

description: Their BBQ Pork is the best of town. My mom brought that one time. I love it so much. Their chickens and roasted duck taste good anf very fresh. And the young lady waitress there has very friendly customer services. I always order togo food here! Highly recommended!
author: Vanessa L.

description: Best roast duck and soy sauce chicken in town!! Get there early so they don't sell out.  Bring your own plastic bag if you don't want to pay for one.  But there's always a short line.
author: Lilian T.

description:
On the quick: one of the best spots to enjoy roasted Chinese-style duck and pork in SF. A work colleague took me here and it's a typical hole
In the wall. The line of blue collar folks waiting to get their lunch told me this was a treat like mom would make. Let me tell you... I took one bite and I was laughing out loud after I tasted the fatty pork neck!.... damn, it's so good is crazy.

*note: don't get the lean pork, get the fatty pork! Oh my god!*
author: Steve B.

description: There is very little I can add to the reviews.  Their food is da bomb.  It would probably speed up your order if you speak Chinese.
author: John G.

description: The princess chicken is a staple when I come to visit my grandparents house. The butcher cuts it perfectly and cuts off the odds and ends. Truly a master with the knife. Tried ordering the tongue but that is only served Friday, Saturday, and Sunday so that was a bummer. The fried pork belly was also out that day but that just means it is yummy! Too bad I couldn't get any that day though. Other then that, this place is dependable for quality food and nice customer service.
author: Kathleen N.

description:
My family used to purchase whole ducks from here on a regular basis. Their booming business hasn't changed, but I feel their quality has slightly. The plates range from $7-$9 roughly, though the chicken and duck pieces given are more bony and meaty. Maybe I'll request for more meaty parts as other reviewers have mentioned. $20 for an entire duck though?! I can definitely get cheaper elsewhere and for a bigger duck as well. Too bad as I used to love their duck growing up. Also, the duck is a bit too salty now for my taste. 

This is more of a to-go place. If you choose to dine in, don't expect much service, especially during peak dining hours. Street parking around the area is decent. All in all, decent to get your craving fixed if you don't want to venture to the sunset!
author: Kristi T.

description: My childhood Asian deli. Really good food. Nothing else to really say. I grew up eating their food.
author: Jacky C.

description:
They're famous for their Princess chicken! I know folks that live in the Sunset come out to order chicken from here. I've been ordering their chicken for almost two decades and their quality was just as good as ever.

They were closed for about a year due to a fire but they opened up again and still have been kicking since.

Just order at the counter and the butcher will help chop up a fresh serving of yummy Princess chicken for you. They are the only ones that include a portion of ahp sun if you ask and their house made gerng chung ginger leek dipping is all you need to serve the chicken.

If you're ordering for a holiday like Lunar New Year, skip the long queue for the butcher and pay at the cashier for your order. Sometimes it's worth the hassle to chop it yourself if you can save yourself from being in line for half an hour.
author: Anna F.

description:
Great place to get canto-style BBQ. $15? minimum for credit (contrary to other reviews).

If you come here on weekends, get here early! They close at 7, but often they'll run out of food to sell by 6.
author: Nathan K.

description: I came here during lunch time. I was waiting in line to get a roast duck. An lady customer bought an half roast duck and she compliant to an older lady why they give her an half roast duck has too much fat. Then the older lady who work at this restaurant was extremely upset. She then cut a piece from an half roast duck left and showed it to the customer that the roast duck has a lot of fat and it's from the same roast duck. The older lady who work at this restaurant was shouting out at the lady customer in Chinese for 5 minutes long. This is insane. At least be respectful to each other, they're all Chinese. This restaurant is drama. The older lady works here is rude to their customers. Clearly, she didn't cared about the customer service and didn't cared about the restaurant reputation. The older lady is really rude. Horrible customer service!!
author: T B.

description: Some of the best roast duck, chau siu BBQ pork, and soy sauce chicken! At slightly over 10 bucks, you can get a combo with rice and some veggies.
author: Haymen D.

description: Haven't been back to this gem for a while. Still super legit. Probably the best chasiu and Siu mei in San Francisco!
author: Wayne T.

description: The only place on Ocean that serves Chinese BBQ. I usually come here when I am too lazy to drive to Chinatown or the Sunset. This shop has been around since I was a kid and has gotten popular over the years with customers coming from around the city for their BBQ. I usually come here for their Princess Yellow Chicken, Soy Sauce Chicken, Roast Duck, BBQ Pork and the Duck Tongue. The chicken here has a very good texture and is very tender. The duck here is greasy and salty. The duck tongue is well brined. They also offer BBQ pork with cuts that are fatty and not fatty with different cuts from the neck or jowl. Since I live in the neighborhood, the owners and staff tend to recognize me and know what my family usually gets. Place gets busy before dinner, make sure to come early or place a phone order beforehand. They tend to close early in the recent years when they sell out and will not make more food afterwards. A long standing business on Ocean, hopefully they stay around for years to come.
author: Peter C.

description: Ming Kee is famous for their Hong Kong style ducks and chickens. They moved a couple times here and there and their ducks and chickens still taste the same. Juicy and tender! I bought their entire roasted duck today and you won't believe how tender and juicy they were! Especially the duck sauce that comes out after they slice the meat. It's super delicious and tender! You bet I will be back to Ming Kee! So why the 4 stars? The line gets long and sometimes they mess up your order by giving it to another person by accident. Other than that, I am a huge fan of their ducks and chickens.
author: Brenda C.

description:
One thing nice about this Chinese BBQ place is that they cook new batches of the menu items continuously so what's displayed for sale stays fresh.

Free range chicken, which is listed on the round eye menu as "yellow chicken" is also on the menu.

Don't feel like taking your meal home? They have a few tables where you can sit and order from the menu. Service and the menu is basic, but the price is right.
author: Glen L.

description: Best spot to get your duck fix. I have become a usual at this location ordering their roast duck and BBQ pork on rice combo plate. The food is delicious and has a Hong Kong feel to it.
author: Melbin A.

description: Don't recommend going here, ate here right in the morning and saw the workers puts the duck in the microwave to heat back up!! Not fresh!!! Came home with a stomachache
author: Alex L.

description: My go-to neighborhood place for Chinese BBQ. I'd probably drive out to this place even if it wasn't in my neighborhood. I usually get the roast duck and BBQ pork over rice. The rice plates come with veggies and usually comes out to ~$10. I guess it's on the pricier side for BBQ but I can't complain because they've never let me down with their food. They never talk to me in English but it's ok because whenever I tell them my order, they get it right and I leave with a full meal in my hands. They have a few tables if you want to dine in.
author: Hayoung K.

description: This is one of the better Chinese bbq places in SF Bay Area. You used to be able to get good chicken or duck anywhere in Chinatown, Richmond District or the Sunset. That has changed. Many of the old favorites are gone or not the same quality or taste that I remember growing up. Ming Kee has it all: poached chicken, soy sauce chicken, bbq pork, roast duck and my new fave..bbq pork neck. It has a tasty layer of fat with tender meat, so not for those who are squeamish about fatty meat. But if you're a bacon and pork lover with no issues, you MUST try this. Amazing with white rice. You can order meats to go or sit at one of their tables and order one of the rice plates with these bbq delicacies. I have noticed the portions have gotten a little smaller but still a tasty lunch deal. Service is very casual. Lots of Chinese contractors come for lunch here. Contractors always know where the good cheap eats are. They serve hot tea. I think the ladies who serve you are kind and polite. Kind of like eating at your friends house when I was growing up and their mom feeds you.
author: Carrie W.

description:
Still my favorite joint for Chinese roasties. 

I was heartbroken when the fire burned em down two years ago. I slowly watched em rebuild from the ground up. MK had a temporary location on Irving during the remodel. 

I've been coming here for ages. First, I don't like char siu (Chinese BBQ pork). In fact, I hate char Siu baos (BBQ pork buns). Ming Kee's char Siu is the only one I eat. Sounds snobbish of me but it's true. They've got the marinade on lock. Only problem with MK is consistency ever since they reopened. 

Secondly, I love their chicken. Soy sauce chicken, yellow hair chicken YUM. Extra ginger scallion sauce for me. I could eat that ginger scallion sauce with a bowl of rice on its own. You know what else? I don't even actually like chicken!! 

If you're in luck and MK has roast goose available, you should get it because it's DAMN GOOD. Just the right amount of meat, fat, grease etc. mmmmmm. This is a rare thing though and it depends on availability.


Sometimes there's a long line, especially before dinner. It's best to plan on getting there a couple hours before the rush and taking it home for dinner. This also will most likely get you the better pieces and cuts of roasties.. If not, it's slim pickins for ya!
author: Susy C.

description: They sell out early before store closing so get there ASAP if you want your pick other than the left overs. Their soy sauce chicken is the best. Incredible moist and tender...even the white meat part which is hard typically dry. Well seasoned without being salty. Their duck and BBQ pork are also tasty but not as good as Lam Hoa Thuan on Irving.
author: Julie L.

description: Best chicken in the bay . We have their food every week, it's the place to go when we don't have time to cook . Their BBQ pork and roasted duck are good too !
author: Dafo W.

description:
*Sits down at a table*

Lady #1: "We don't serve chow mein here."
Me *thinking*: "What the phuck--do I have 'I want chow mein' written on my forehead?'"

*Placed order with Lady #2*

Lady #1 yells at Lady #2 in canto: "The yellow free range chicken costs $2 more, ask the American couple if they still want it."
Me: "Yes, that's fine" to Lady #2.

*Received our rice plates*

Me: "Excuse me, we also ordered the chai siu, the neck portion."
Lady #1 yells at Lady #2 in canto: "Tell the American couple it's more expensive for that cut; it's $8, ask them if they still want it."

Dayam yo, not only do I look like an "American" (I'm 3/4ths Chinese) but I look like a cheap American that wants chow mein?

*Le Sigh*

OTHER NOTES:
*Expect a line out the door on the weekends with aggressive and pushy customers. Beware of line cutters.  
*Ming Kee (formerly named Happy Bakery & Deli) reopened last week after burning down from a fire 1.5 years ago (my review: http://bit.ly/M4Ku2P). They had a temporary location on Irving street for 8 months (my review: http://bit.ly/1jWZCeK).
*Ming Kee is a Chinese deli that sells your typical roast meats. For chicken, you have a choice of regular or "yellow" free range chicken which is a lot bonier but has more flavor. 
*Signature items: Princess Chicken (free range steamed chicken w/ ginger & scallion sauce) & Soy Sauce Chicken.
*MUST ORDER the Cha Siu: BBQ Pork jowl/neck portion ($8): http://bit.ly/1clFDEU
*Staff doesn't speak or understand much English.
*6-7 tables for seating
*CASH ONLY
*Reason for downgrade from their previous locations?

A) Prices are 18-28% higher than their previous locations. For example, a whole duck was $15 and is now $19. Rice plate combos were $7ish and are now $9.50.

B) Quality seems to have declined and/or we got a bad batch. I ordered the Princess Chicken & Soy Sauce Chicken Combo ($8.50 + $2 for free range "yellow" chicken): http://bit.ly/1d4O2s6. The free-range princess chicken was not as good as I remembered it to be and the ginger-scallion sauce needed more oil. The free-range soy sauce chicken was horrible; it was like incredibly dry turkey breast meat and it was hella salty.

C) Unprofessional behavior. Lady #1 kept ordering Lady #2 around (to clear tables, take orders, and grab tea) and rudely yelled at her on multiple occasions in front of customers. Granted, I found some of her comments (about us) to be comical but I felt really bad for Lady #2 as she seemed bullied and embarrassed. Even if it's a "culture" thing, unless your Gordon Ramsay, disrespecting your staff in front of customers just doesn't fly.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
$10/lb roast pork

$9.75/ half of a duck

50 cents or 25 cents for the sauce.

Opens at 10am
author: Jboogie L.

description:
This place use to be excellent in terms of the meat they sell. Since the place burned down, the owners moved to Irving St and recently relocated back to Ocean Avenue.

For some reason, the products are not as good as it use to be but still better than most spots when it comes to BBQ pork, soy sauce chicken, quail, regular chicken and duck! All the meats are flavorful and tender!

This is great place for take out meats to bring home and enjoy but there are seating for people who choose to eat there. Although most of their business comes from customers who buy to go more than sit down service. 

They are pretty well known for their chicken and bbq pork and most of the time sells out before dinner time. They are also a bit pricier than most bbq pork places but thats because their quality is better.

Be careful especially on special holidays, they tend to sell out even faster!

Also be careful to phone in orders, I have been there in line and here many customers complain that they phone in order but their order was given to other customers. 

Tip: try to get there before 7pm since most nights they sell out of certain meats.
author: Joanne K.

description:
Ok. This review is for the BBQ pork (char Sui). I was searching for a place where I can get some really good meats that was from a clean place with a health score higher than 80. Lol- I hate walking into a place where they chop meat and the environment is a bit sketchy. 

Any who, I have to say-the BBQ pork here is really, really, really good!! I couldn't stop eating it. I bought 2 small slabs of it and ate it- fat and all. Yum ! 

I will be heading back for the Peking duck and their soy sauce chicken. Can't wait !
author: William Y.

description:
We moved to this neighborhood recently and I was trying to figure out which of the many chinese restaurants along Ocean Avenue were the best. When in doubt - follow the lines! On New Year's Eve I noticed a long line of all Chinese people queuing up outside this place which was a big vote of confidence for me! 
I wasn't disappointed - they do really excellent roast pork, roast duck and roast chicken - not too fatty, well seasoned, reasonable prices - delicious! My go-to for a quick and easy family dinner meal now is to order a whole or half duck/ chicken plus their white rice which is simple but cooked well. My 3 year old loves the duck as do the rest of us.
There's usually a line but it moves fast except when they sell out of something and then you have to wait 15 min or more for the next batch of poultry to be ready. Worth the wait!  
(You can also order ahead for a pickup if worried about things running out).
author: Sushi K.

description:
Whenever I need something quick and flavorful for dinner, I can usually depend on Ming Kee deli. 

My fave go-to's are the soy sauce chicken and bbq pork. 

This place is definitely more of a traditional Chinese deli. For those who are squeamish, just know that the head and feet are still attached to the ducks and chickens before serving. For those who are a bit more adventurous, they do sell boiled chicken feet by the pound. 

Their line moves quickly. Service is pretty straightforward; not necessarily rude and not necessarily polite either. I guess you can kind of relate it to the Soup Nazi in the regimented way you have to order your food. I would recommend that indecisive people should not approach the counter until absolutely ready to order. I would hate to infuriate the stone-faced man with the meat cleaver behind the glass case. Yowzas!

Point at what you want, bada bing bada boom, and you're off to the register. There's plenty of seating for dine-in patrons. Prices are very reasonable. Orders usually come out to approximately $10. Keep in mind that this place is ca$h money onlyyyy.
author: Ann S.

description: They don't have roast pork!! My family and I came and each got a rice plate, can substitute the rice for egg noodles in soup. I had the soy sauce princess chicken and duck combo. Comes with the ginger onion side and cooked lettuce. Pretty good but I got a lot of bones. Tried the bbq pork and it was really moist, would get that next time. There are always people in line ordering take out.
author: Linz C.

description: I have started coming here a lot recently for lunch. Good, affordable, authentic Chinese BBQ with large rice portions, attentive service.
author: James C.

description:
I LOVE IT. It has the best CHASHU I have had compared to other places. I ate the whole CHASHU on my own. I couldn't stop eating it! I LOVE IT. I ordered #1, the Chashu & Chicken Plate.

CHASHU: the meat is freshly roasted. I can tell because it is not hard and dry. The meat is quite flushed and soft so this is good meat. The honey glazed on top is pretty good. It can be a bit more because certain parts of the meat is sweeter than some. But definitely it is good because most places will roast it....leave it there...no one buys...then re-roast to make it hot again. That makes the meat dry + more dry and the honey is kind of no more. MING KEE makes it good :)

Chicken: The chicken is not too dry either which is pleasant to me. I usually do not eat chicken very much but this is quite delicious, especially that ginger sauce they make. 

THUMBS UP! TRY IT!
author: Katie P.

description: Almost don't want to give the secret away but I have to. Best HK roast duck in SF. And I've tried them all, believe me. They sell out each day. Nuff said.
author: Max G.

description: This old lady is so rude and mean. She is giving customer bad attitude. She was recommending me other chicken but I want roast duck and she said there is no more. I was about to leave and she called me back. I asked if there is the whole duck and she is said no, you order the rice in a rude way. I would accept it if she is saying nicely
author: Jenny S.

description: Came here for lunch and got the roast duck to go. Service was fast, though you could have some problems ordering if you don't speak any Chinese! The roast duck was delicious and fatty! Definitely a great alternative to Cheung Hing if you live near here and don't want to drive that far! Though the duck is pretty good, the price was a bit expensive for the amount of duck they gave me.. Which leads me to docking off one star. Other than that, great place to grab takeout!
author: Fiona H.

description:
Came here because after watching The God of Cookery by Stephen Chow, I crave for the same 黯然销魂饭(barbecued pork over rice), hahaha.

I was seated pretty quickly at 1pm on a Saturday. Barbecued pork was good, not too sweet like a lot of other places, it comes with vegies on the side, I was full after finishing it and satisfied.  

Now that I have been here a couple more times, I think it deserves four stars.
author: Cheng C.

description: They gave me too much rice to make the meal looks big. They knows how to cut chicken to make it looks there is a lot of pieces in a meal. The price is not cheap but the food tastes great. Typical Chinese restaurant with rush service.
author: Li L.

description: clean fresh chinese bbq! mini char siu was bomb.com! soy sauce yellow hair chicken and roasted duck on point.
author: Bee Z.

description:
I can name a couple of places in San Francisco outside its Chinatown that may require assistance from someone that knows how to speak either Cantonese or Mandarin - Ming Kee, is one of those places.

My intention going to this place is to get a rice plate with some BBQ pork, rice and some veggie sides from what I've seen people order. Lo and behold after i left the establishment, I was $35 poorer. For some reason I ended up getting an entire Chicken costing $18, a togo box of BBQ pork and another box of Fat(apparently it's called pork cheeks). 

Chicken - I meant to get what's called the Soy chicken, but instead I was given "the yellow chicken". It was more expensive than what I initially wanted, and quite honestly, I didn't like it. I found the meat to be tough and chewy, while the skin was extra chewy as well.

BBQ Pork - I actually loved their BBQ pork, well cooked and tender without being overly salty.

Pork Cheeks - Double the price of the BBQ pork, and i'd say 80% was just fat! 

Next time that I go here, I;ll make sure that I bring someone with me to translate.

PS. This place gets really busy in the afternoon.. line out the door kind of busy!!
author: Jan R.

description:
Pros

Good duck
Good chicken
Good pork

Cons

Almost $20 for a duck,  WTFuc
Rice plates not cheap
Service cutters grumpy
Quit cutting in front of me in line, lady A-moo

Place was better before it burned down.  Now it's more expensive and less friendly.  Food still makes it happen.
author: John L.

description: Really high quality bbq pork, duck and chicken. Consistenly solid, and fills me up everytime. My comfort food. Would go again.
author: Nathan W.

description: Finally make it to the city today just to try the BBQ pig neck and cheek meat.  I did call ahead as other suggested and got them to hold 2lb of each for me.  I arrived around 11:45 and luckily beat the lunch crowd.  We ordered two combos there: BBQ pork and Princess Yellow Chicken over rice and the Soy sauce yellow chicken and roast duck over rice.  Everything is excellent.  We added a princess yellow chicken on the to go list, total comes to $68.  Good service with super price, this place would be my must stop spot in the city from now on.
author: Ed Q.

description: Some of the best Chinese BBQ I've ever had. Try the roast duck, BBQ pork, and pork neck.
author: Andy F.

description: I ordered pork and soy chicken lunch box. The chicken was Stinky. I told the female boss ( The old lady) she was so rude. She had very Terrible service. I won't go back anymore. I suggest health department should come to check this restaurant because many students and workers buy lunch here often.
author: Hsinyi L.

description: I've been coming here for a while now. The food is excellent. I like there BBQ spareribs and their duck. Very tasty
author: Peter N.

description:
Went and order a box of duck over rice to go, Ming Kee asked me what I want again, I told him I wanted duck over rice to go. He said I don't understand you, so I said how do you like
me to explain, draw a duck over the while rice. He went quite. I go there when he is not there, if he is tired then he should work in the kitchen. Poor customer service...
author: Darlene C.

description:
Praised by some of my mother's friends as one of the best butcher shops in SF (competition would be fierce among all the options in Chinatown, Sunset, and Richmond district), I figured I'd fulfill my filial and Yelp duties by actually giving this place a try. 

Prices are a little higher (I believe) than some other butcher places, but I'm more than willing to pay extra for the cleanliness and sanitary interior of this place. A whole chicken was 18.00 and half a roasted duck was 8.50, both butchered for me on the spot. 

The chicken was juicy and tender, excellent on its own, but what really brought this over the top was the minced-pureed garlic/ginger dipping sauce it came with. The sauce was amazing, scrumptious paired with the chicken or even just mixed with rice. (makes more sense why they would charge extra if additional "concoction" was requested- since it was offered as an option for me, but I kindly declined)

The roasted duck was equally delicious (although way more fatty- dripping with oil). Highly recommend microwaving this for 30 seconds or so for the extra grease to come out before consuming. Overall, equally impressed by the goods and hygienics of Ming Kee.
author: Ada C.

description: I live in the neighbor and have been here for many times. The food is 4-5 stars. However the service is only 1 star. They speak to customers in a impatient manner in store or by the phone. They told me I can call to order in advance and pick up when I get off from work. Today, I called to order at 6pm and let them know I would pick it up before they close at 7pm. They said they won't wait for me because they can sell the last two ducks to others and close the store earlier than 7pm. So what's the point to call to order? They don't know or don't want to develop long term customers.
author: Fangfang O.

description: i had roasted pigeon and soy sauce pigeon here.  the taste is good and meat is soft.   i recommend it to anyone who like HK style BBQ and pigeon.
author: Kin W.

description: Soy sauce chicken was very tasty and moist, a plus. Yet there was nothing left to buy when I got there on a late afternoon (2 hours before closing), no roast pork, no BBQ pork (chashu), no yellow chicken, no duck. I was ready to buy two items, but could only have one. What was their plan for the remaining two hours of opened business? Tell every single person they only had soy sauce chicken? And even at that, when I bought mine, there was only two left. Minus two stars.
author: Dom L.

description: you gotta have half lean half FAY bbq pork there, hella legit!
author: Deen L.

description: I honestly love this place.. it's right across from my house (thank goodness). Although the prices are pretty steep compared to sunset/chinatown prices.. I just love how convenient this place is. My favorite has to be their yellow chicken as well as their roasted duck.. sometimes though they sell out quick so I like to get there early to ensure I get my hands on their yummy food. I normally will buy half of a yellow chicken and half a roasted duck.. total comes out to around $18.00.
author: Eleana H.

description: Came with my parents and sister for some duck and chicken.  This place is small, casual, don't expect anything fancy.  They gave us each our own tea bag which was nice and unusual for a Chinese restaurant.  The menu is small -- chicken, duck, pork or a combination thereof over either rice or noodle soup.  I opted for the soy sauce chicken and duck over noodles.  Duck was flavorful and not too fatty.  I even got a couple of really meaty pieces.  Chicken was moist and the side of minced garlic/green onion/ginger that they serve it with is delicious!  I had my portion of the sauce and my sister's and I still couldn't get enough.   My mom got the BBQ which was good as well.  My only complaint is that they serve their rice plates with a side of lettuce.  Is cabbage that much more expensive?!?  That aside, this is one of the best meals under $10 you can get in SF.
author: L C.

description: This place is insanely delicious. I don't even like Chashu and this place has me constantly thinking about whether I can cop an order before they sell out. Not to mention that their ginger sauce is off the hook.
author: Jessica O.

description:
The highly lauded soy sauce chicken was dry as was the char siu.  There was very little meat on the duck.  

We went for lunch so I'm sure the food was freshly made.  Service was friendly. 

As for me, I'll stick with my go-to places on Irving and Clement Streets.
author: Debbie T.

description:
I'm a bit torn about Ming Kee.

They are now finally back in their original location. 2+ years ago a fire took down the bakery next door as well as MK (known as Happy Bakery & Deli then), and the entire structure housing the two had to be torn down and rebuilt.

In the interim, Ming Kee rented a spot and moved to Irving Street (where Guangdong BBQ is currently), and they soared to great heights with a killer stir fry mini selection from a secret weapon chef that they hired (who was actually the former sous chef at Yum's Bistro in Fremont, most of you who follow my FOB tips know how much I worship Chef Yum and his art). Unfortunately after they shut down the Irving location, the stir fry chef either stayed on with Guangdong or left for other pastures. It seemed that cheap a$$ local$ thought MK was super overpriced, and they preferred lower quality competitor Lam Hoa Thuan Restaurant's roasties down the street, and sadly higher quality MK could not compete with that ingrained thinking. It just goes to show that some people prefer value with lower quality over something that may cost just a tad more but you get so much more mileage. What can I say. A$N cheapen$$ can sometimes manifest into a mental disorder in the wrong direction. 

But the king being back, unfortunately does not translate to a happy kingdom at the moment. The king was out of comission for at least a year, and seemed to have lost his mojo. The king still has a lot of loyal fans in the hood, so if there are picky buggers (or Yelpers for that matter) it's no loss in the short term. Locals seem unphased by the negative reviews thus far. 

A few issues with the current Ming Kee (now back in the original location)

- prices seemed to have crept up a bit
- consistency and quality seem to fluctuate depending on your roll of the dice and time of day. 
- no more stir fry, like in the previous Irving location
- stripped down dine in menu of mostly rice plates and a few other things
- reports of inability to pick and choose the specific cuts of roasties you want and being given the bad ones (could be the entire batch is not prime that day)
- customization of rice plates (e.g an off menu pairing of certain roasties combinations) may be met with re$i$tance in the form of unexpected price increa$e$.

As well as other random issues. 

But really...where else are you going to find half decent roasties in this area? In some ways, Ming Kee has retained that neighborhood deli flavor. For me I will continue to patronize them and not Cheung Hing, who don't know how to properly season and process their roasties (and no, mass and volume does not mean quality).
 
FOBenese quicktips on MK:

- MK cuts their cha siu (BBQ pork) a lot thinner than the competition. The marination is on the sweeter side. Eat this with rice for best results. Order leanest cut, because you might end up with some fatty pieces. If you are adventurous, try pairing with garlic bread at home, or a banh mi with other seasonings. Or create the "golden chicken coin" and mash it up with chicken liver...

- I would wait a while before ordering crispy skin roast pork. They may still be trying to figure out roasting with the new rig.

- BBQ pork neck meat (jowl) is fantastic but uber fatty. Of course it is pricier, there are only two cheeks to a pig. Don't be $hocked if it costs a bit more. Indulge in moderation.

- soy sauce chicken, as delicious as always

- ask for a container of ginger scallion oil. You might pay a little more but it adds to the experience.

- for best results, dine in, unless you plan to eat your takeout immediately after getting home. It is cash only so bring ample bills. For even better results, get one rice plate and entrees (no rice) of roasties.

- roast goose depends on your luck. The luck being a combination of availability and nailing it down where it tastes reasonable. Availability is already a mini jackpot, so don't push your luck too much just yet. 

I hope they overcome the issues with consistency and perhaps scaling. 

In the old movie, I believe Stella did get her groove back. I can only hope MK will in time as well.
author: Ken K.

description: If you like chinese bbq, i would recommended this place. Their roast duck is the bomb. The meat is nice and juice. The skin is crisp.
author: Joseph S.

description: This place has the best soy sauce chicken.  Every time we are going to SF, we will find a way to stop by this place to order soy sauce chicken to take home.  We like their cold duck tongues, wings and feet as well.  We have been going there over 20 year and never make you disappointed.
author: Rainbow O.

description: Great Hong-Kong style bbq place... but when you're ordering lunch plates with duck-- make sure you ask them to throw out the neck unless that's your thing.. but I really prefer my pieces to be meaty than boney.
author: Terinna R.

description: This place is the best chinese deli.  Besides the line.  Also when they run out of stuff.
author: claudia y.

description:
I'm a student of City College at Ocean. I always come here for lunch since I really like Chinese food, especially in the cold and rainy day. I give five starts based on their yummy food and affordable price. Even though the environment is not so nice. I like their roast  duck so much!  To me their roast duck and chicken are number one in the city. 
The service is pretty quickly. If you want to take out, you have to wait in line , otherwise you just need to have a seat and wait for ordering your meal.  So far, food to go, only the chicken legs and dirk wings are kind too much soft and too much less salted, others are pretty taste. 
By the way, no tip is required if you eat there. That's pretty cool!  You also can call to order your meal!
author: Yan M.

description: If you want quick, simple, affordable, huge rice plates with duck, chicken, and Bbq pork piled on top, then this place is a must see.  It took no more than 5 mins for us to get our food. All the meats were absolutely delicious, especially eaten with large scoops of white rice! Fed 5 for under $50. And, we were on our way, albeit a little heavier, within 35 mins.  It's no wonder these people have a continuous line going out the door.  Interior decor was not a priority, but that makes the food taste that much better. NOTE: If you think Pandas is good Chinese, then this place is not for you.
author: Dean B.

description:
The king is back indeed! 

You know the drill. Super long lines even on weekends and even the places on Irving would envy this. It beats being on Irving, and this was confirmed by the owners when I spoke with them earlier. 

It's also plenty cleaner since it's all new! Out even boasts a Food Safety Score of 94, on top of a Servsafe certificate. 

And sorry there is no chow mein or pad thai here -- you can get that at PF Chang or Panda Express.
author: Kevin N.

description:
Lost a star for service.

You do not come here for the service!!! But the food is awesome! Love the fact that I do not have to make my way to Chinatown for some decent Chinese deli food!

My only advice is try to avoid rush time. That way you can get in n out fast! I've seen the line go out and around!!!
author: Catherine K.

description: good place for bbq meat. nothing great, just good. portions are decent. better for take-out as the place isnt very cozy to dine in and customer service is somewhat lacking (typical for cantonese restaurants; direct and straight to the point, not very friendly or smiley) and english isnt widely spoken here. come earlier before closing as they often tend to be sold out by 5-6pm daily.
author: p f.

description: A good place to get Chinese style chicken, which hands down is their specialty!  I do remembered the chicken being a bit more moist before they got burnt down a couple years back.  But despite the chicken not as good as it was before, comparing to other Cantonese roasted meat places, it is still the go-to place for chicken as most of the other places make their chicken too dry and not as flavorful.
author: Rose L.

description: The main attraction here are the Chinese barbecue meats. The food is great. Service is minimal and pretty much as expected from standard Chinese delis.
author: Cecilia Y.

description: Bit more pricey for their free range chicken and duck but they do it well. Very juicy and its deboned.
author: Ju D.

description: Ate here couple of times, but will never ever again. Saw lady who looks like owner take vegetables off a table after customers left and put back in pot behind counter.
author: Ed C.

description: Only the best roast duck in San Francisco.  I am so glad they reopened after they got burnt down.
author: Alex C.

description: don't usually come here but wanted to try this place out. I got the bbq pork over rice. it was ready pretty quickly -I was lucky it wasn't that busy when I came in. So they give you a lot of rice. Its basically like 80% rice, topped with 10% bbq pork and 10% lettuce..but it was pretty good.
author: Carmen L.

description: This place is one of my favorite places to get roasted pork neck and roasted bbq pork. They also have amazing chicken and really good duck (good fat, meat, and crispiness ratio). If you want good Chinese bbq, this is definitely a gotta try spot.
author: Adelbert Y.

description: They have decent food there, but today we got ripped off. My dad bought a whole roasted duck for $18, it came with half the breast missing. Cheap move by them. Keep an eye on them when they chop up your food and box them, bastards...
author: Alex Z.

description: Never seen this place before and its less than 10 minutes away. I'm glad I tried this place because it has a delicious duck/BBQ pork plate. For 9 dollars, you get rice, veggie, two meats and this onion thing you put onto duck. You need to speak Chinese to order or point to the menu item. Overall the service is meh but the food is legit.
author: Ricky C.

description: Food quality ok. But services not great. It took longer than 15 mins to get our preordered item.
author: Ruthie C.

description: It was decent. Quick and simple. I had the roast duck and BBQ pork rice combo plate. Better then I expected...duck was very tasty. Will come back again.
author: Phi N.

description: The food is taste but beware chickens are bones in.  The owner is an old lady chief commander "yellow chicken"  you will notice her the first you step in this place.  She likes to micro manage every details and manipulate her staff which i really don't care but her voice is really breaking my ear drums!  Peaceful is what we missed....
author: Cookie M.

description: Typical Chinese restaurant, no wonder CHINESE restaurant can't make it big and famous like the American restaurant. They are rude and don't know how to treat customer and they nickel and dime you on everything, extra for  an take out container, extra for sauce. Their prices went up a lot already and they still want to squeeze more out of the customers. You don't really want to put up with their crap. You can do yourself a favor and take your business elsewhere where you will be treated a lot nicer.
author: Allie T.

description: I have never tried the food here, however, I'm giving it ONE STAR because of the poor customer service. I couldn't find the menu online so I called to get an idea on the prices and what they have for an entree. The woman who speaks limited English said "no we don't have the menu, ok thank you". Wtf??? Do you NOT want businesses? I was going to place a to-go order but guess not. I tried to get her attention and by speaking very slowly; "How much for food?" to break it down for her and make it easier. But she said "No, we don't have food. Thank you". Uhm..that's super awkward. Look, I appreciate authentic ethnic food, so authentic that the staff don't speak English well (it is San Francisco after all!) but when  you can not tell people how much your entrees are, AND there isn't a menu available online, there's a huge problem with how you're running your business. If how they run the business is indicative of their food, I would not go there. Guess I dodged a bullet. Bye!
author: Clint S.

description: Not sure what people are whining about customer service for, the lady came over and I got what I ordered, I spoke to her in English and she understood me just fine, I mean its a simple order, if they didn't understand me I can point at the menu, This is normal at most Chinese restaurants. I'm half Chinese half Peruvian so I dont really look like either, still no one was rude, service was timely and everything tasted great. I ordered the Roast Duck and Char Siu Pork plate and my friend had the Yellow Chicken, Both dishes were out in about 5 minutes, The bill came out to $15 not including tip, Which is really cheap for 2 people, we were both full and satisfied. I came here because of how busy it looked one day walking by, now other reviews also say these people are pushy and such, they must not have much experience living in the city, if you want to be treated like a princess expect to pay a bit more than $8 a plate, if you want a nice quick meal for cheap, this is your place.
author: Bruce W.

description: After it's reopening after the fire incident. I've been here many times. I have not been disappointed once. On the first day it reopened, I attended and had a dine in. I had roasted duck with rice and cabbage. It was extremely tasty. The roasted duck was not flavored with so much spice that you had to drink gallons of water after, but wasn't flavored too little to have no taste of what you ate. What stood out to me the most was the personalities of the workers. Each and everyone of them, let it be the custodian or the store owner, were absolutely kind. How do I know? When it came the time to pay( it came up to a total of $6.75 for a Roast duck plate, again, very worth for the price paid!) I only had a debit card on me. (I didn't read the $15 minimum for the use of a bank card.) While everyone looked at me like I was one of those people who ate without paying, the store owner told me with a reassuring voice that it was okay, and to bring cash next time. Then she made sure everyone knew that everything was settled. I left a $5 tip because the workers were truly amazing. If there were to a negative, it would be the trouble to find parking. Ocean Avenue is normally very crowded with cars. Other than that, I highly recommend this restaurant. Couldn't have asked for better!
author: Brandon H.
